channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: North American Leaders Urged to Restore Monarch Butterfly’s Habitat
item.description: A group of prominent scientists and writers urged Mexico, the United States and Canada to commit to restoring the habitat that supports the insect’s migration across the continent.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Sales of Iranian Crude Oil Rose in January
item.description: The increase of 100,000 barrels a day, to 1.32 million, appeared to reflect the impact of an easing of sanctions under a temporary nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Thai Police Clear Areas of Protesters as Their Numbers Ebb
item.description: Protesters have failed to “shut down” Bangkok as they vowed last month, but a hard-core group of protesters numbering in the thousands remains defiant.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Thai police removed a makeshift tire barrier at an antigovernment protest camp in Bangkok on Friday.

item.title: Volcanic Eruption in Indonesia Closes 3 Airports
item.description: Ash shrouded a large section of the country’s most densely populated island, Java; closed three international airports; and sent thousands fleeing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indian Publisher Withdraws Book, Stoking Fears of Nationalist Pressure
item.description: A retired headmaster’s campaign has led Penguin Books India to agree to destroy copies of a book deemed offensive to Hindus, prompting fears that an ideological shift was underway.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dinanath Batra, a right-wing campaigner, who forced Penguin Books India to agree to destroy remaining copies of Wendy Doniger’s “The Hindus: An Alternative History.”

item.title: The Lede: Images of Turkish Reporter Felled by Police Water Cannon Stir Anger Online
item.description: Outraged Turkish bloggers and journalists shared images of a female television reporter who was knocked down by a direct blast from a police water cannon during a protest in the capital, Anakara, on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Prominent Opposition Leader in Venezuela Is Blamed for Unrest
item.description: Leopoldo López, a former mayor of a district of Caracas, said the government was responsible for the deadly violence during antigovernment protests.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: The opposition leader Leopoldo López during an antigovernment protest on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Urged to Act on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
item.description: The United Nations top official for emergency operations said the cease-fire in Homs — the only achievement from peace talks — cannot be considered “progress,” and aid workers should be able to do their work without getting shot.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: In Prison Release, Signs of Karzai’s Rift With U.S.
item.description: American military officials have been publicly scathing in their criticism of the releases, which have brought relations between the two allies to a low point.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAWAD SUKHANYAR and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghan National Army soldiers stand guard at Bagram prison north of Kabul on Thursday.

item.title: A Russian Protest Zone Where Almost No One Registers a Complaint
item.description: A park designated as the official protest site of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, whose main arenas are about 10 miles away, highlights how the Russian government often smothers dissent under a thick blanket of bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A small park in Khosta, Russia, was designated as a protest zone for the Winter Olympics in Sochi, about 10 miles away.

item.title: Free Online University Receives Accreditation, in Time for Graduating Class of 7
item.description: The University of the People, built to reach underserved students around the world, announced Thursday that it had received accreditation.
item.dc:creator: By TAMAR LEWIN

item.title: Birmingham Journal: As Hate Crimes Rise, British Muslims Say They’re Becoming More Insular
item.description: Backlash after the killing of a soldier by two Muslims last year and a rise in anti-immigrant feelings have made some Muslim residents feel unwelcome.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Schoolchildren on a field trip to the Central Mosque in Birmingham. The city, in the Midlands, is about 20 percent Muslim.

item.title: U.S. Dominance in Science Faces Asian Challenge
item.description: A new report suggests that the rise of increasingly competitive emerging economies, combined with underinvestment in research might translate to a less productive American economy in the future.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:credit: Gary Cosby Jr./The Decatur Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A high school chemistry class in Moulton, Ala. A report said the United States’ share of global research spending had declined.

item.title: Germany to Consider Lifting Statute of Limitations on Cases Involving Stolen Property
item.description: The proposed legislation would make it easier for Jewish families to seek the return of art or other valuables taken by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: N.S.A. Forces Out Civilian Employee With Snowden Tie
item.description: The move comes after an investigation to “assign accountability” for the disclosure of intelligence secrets by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor for the National Security Agency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Kerry Rejects Delaying South Korea Exercise
item.description: The request from North Korea came as Secretary of State John Kerry started a trip to Asia covering several countries and addressing several challenges.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with President Park Geun-hye on Thursday in South Korea, his first stop on a regional trip.

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Deadly Attack on Elite Police Unit
item.description: A bomb in a car killed at least 12 officers in Pakistan’s elite police commando force and wounded 55 people in the southern city of Karachi on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Colombia’s Warning for Mexico
item.description: Local defense groups look better than the drug cartels now, but they could turn out to be just one more illegal army.
item.dc:creator: By HÉCTOR ABAD

item.title: The Lede: Images of Turkish Reporter Felled by Police Water Cannon Stir Anger Online
item.description: Outraged Turkish bloggers and journalists shared images of a female television reporter who was knocked down by a direct blast from a police water cannon during a protest in the capital, Anakara, on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Scientists Hope to Sequence Genome of Richard III
item.description: About a year and a half after finding the king’s corpse, British researchers will grind up his bones in hopes of discovering, for example, what bacteria he might have been hosting.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: University of Leicester , via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Scientists plan to use some of King Richard III’s bones, above, to discover his hair and eye color.

item.title: Belgium Close to Allowing Euthanasia for Ill Minors
item.description: The measure, which is expected to be signed by King Philippe, would make Belgium the first nation to lift all age restrictions on legal, medically induced deaths.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Belgium's lower house of Parliament approved a law allowing euthanasia for terminally ill children who are enduring insufferable pain.

item.title: Indonesian Arms Industry Seeks to Drum Up Business
item.description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono has vowed to modernize the country’s military and has nearly quadrupled the state arms budget.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: The Lede: Videos of Besieged Areas in Syria Highlight Need for Aid Access
item.description: Activists and aid organizations have published footage of the dire aid needs of civilians in besieged areas.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Scots Told They Risk Losing the Pound if They Gain Independence
item.description: After the British prime minister appealed to Scots to reject the independence referendum, Britain’s three main parties sent a more steely message.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Italy’s Prime Minister Announces Resignation Amid Party Revolt
item.description: Prime Minister Enrico Letta said he would resign after his Democratic Party staged a dramatic insurrection and set the stage to replace him with the party’s new leader, Matteo Renzi.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Enrico Letta, above, is likely to be replace by Matteo Renzi, the mayor of Florence.
